title: What Is Scurvy? Symptoms, Causes, Diagnosis, Treatment, and Prevention
author: Moira Lawler
description: Scurvy is a disease caused by vitamin C deficiency. It is rare in the developed world, but certain groups may be more prone to scurvy. Learn more here.
cleaned_text: caused by a deficiency in [vitamin C](/diet-nutrition/vitamin-c/) (aka ascorbic acid), which is rare in the developed world. It doesn't happen overnight, generally setting in after a few months of low vitamin C intake, says [Kelly Springer, RD](https://www.kellyschoice.org/about/our-team/), the owner of Kelly's Choice in Skaneateles, New York. Vitamin C is a key [antioxidant](https://www.everydayhealth.com/diet-nutrition/diet/antioxidants-health-benefits-best-sources-side-effects-more/)that plays many necessary roles, including immune system support, iron absorption, and [collagen](https://www.everydayhealth.com/skin-beauty/collagen-health-benefits-food-sources-supplements-types-more/)production. Scurvy is known for being the disease of pirates and sailors. "Seamen and pirates and explorers got scurvy because they ran out of citrus and other [vitamin C-rich foods](https://www.everydayhealth.com/diet-nutrition/top-foods-high-in-vitamin-c.aspx) on their long journeys," Springer says. Fortunately, scurvy is less of an issue now that we know eating [foods with vitamin C](/diet-nutrition/top-foods-high-in-vitamin-c.aspx) can prevent it, says Michelle Zive, RD, a nutrition coach based in La Mesa, California. "Today, vitamin C deficiency and scurvy are rarely seen in developed countries," she says. [fruits](https://www.everydayhealth.com/diet-nutrition-pictures/the-healthiest-power-fruits-next-door.aspx)and vegetables, and the daily recommended amount is 75 milligrams (mg) for adult women and 90 mg for adult men. The symptoms of scurvy aren't pleasant, but the disease is treatable and easy to recover from. Signs and Symptoms of Scurvy Zive says scurvy usually presents as fatigue and inflamed gums. But symptoms can get worse as the condition progresses. "As deficiency continues, it can lead to joint pain and poor wound healing," Zive says. - Weakness, fatigue, or irritability - Loss of appetite or weight loss - Muscular pain - Sunken or bulging eyes - Paleness [Diarrhea](https://www.everydayhealth.com/diarrhea/) - Increased heart rate or [shortness of breath](/breathing-difficulty/guide/) - Fever - Swelling in joints or gums - Reopening of old wounds - Easy bruising - Dry, scaly skin - Weakness and irritability - Poor wound healing - Bone pain - Loss of appetite - Swollen, bluish gums - Reduced bone formation - Swollen limbs that bruise easily Vitamin C cannot be made by the body — it has to come from vitamin C-rich foods, fortified foods, and supplements — so these symptoms may begin once intake drops and the body's current stores are used up. Causes and Risk Factors of Scurvy Scurvy is the direct result of vitamin C deficiency. Signs of scurvy can manifest with a vitamin C intake below 10 mg per day, says [Tamar Samuels, RD](https://culinahealth.com/tamar-samuels), the cofounder of Culina Health in New York City. - High alcohol intake - Tobacco use - Low income - Being on dialysis [anorexia nervosa](https://www.everydayhealth.com/anorexia-nervosa/guide/), [autism](https://www.everydayhealth.com/autism/), or a developmental delay. Prognosis of Scurvy Duration of Scurvy Treatment and Medication Options for Scurvy Scurvy is generally easy to treat by increasing vitamin C levels. "In mild cases, scurvy can be treated simply with vitamin C-rich foods," Springer says. "The 'five servings of fruits and vegetables per day' rule will provide the recommended daily intake of vitamin C, and will treat mild cases and prevent future cases of scurvy." More severe cases, however, may require supplemental vitamin C, Springer says, and supplementation may also help you heal faster. All management of severe vitamin C deficiency should be under the direction of your healthcare team. Medication Options The only medication to treat scurvy is vitamin C-rich foods and vitamin C supplementation (pill form, intravenous, or injected). - Red and green peppers - Citrus fruits, such as oranges, [pineapple](https://www.everydayhealth.com/diet-nutrition/8-reasons-eat-pineapple/), and [grapefruit](https://www.everydayhealth.com/diet-nutrition/diet/grapefruit-nutrition-benefits-types-side-effects-more/) - Strawberries [Kiwi](https://www.everydayhealth.com/diet-nutrition/diet/what-kiwi-nutrition-health-benefits-risks-recipes/) [Broccoli](https://www.everydayhealth.com/diet-nutrition/diet/broccoli-nutrition-health-benefits-how-prepare-it-more/) - Tomatoes Prevention of Scurvy Springer suggests shooting for five servings of a variety of fruits and vegetables each day. That'll put you at around 200 mg of vitamin C, she says, which gives you a little more than the recommended daily intake, to make sure you're covered. Complications of Scurvy Scurvy can typically be treated easily, but it may lead to long-term issues if it goes untreated. "Depending on the severity of disease, scurvy can be very serious and even fatal," Samuels says. [anemia](/anemia/anemia-basics.aspx), high blood pressure, problems with wound healing, and failure to thrive. Though very rare, there are potential complications associated with scurvy treatment. "Since vitamin C is water soluble — meaning that excessive amounts will be eliminated in the urine — toxic accumulation of vitamin C within the body is extremely unlikely," Springer says. "However, I would still recommend staying below the upper limit of 2,000 mg per day of vitamin C, because too much can cause undesirable side effects, especially for those with kidney problems." [too much vitamin C](/drugs/ascorbic-acid)(generally a concern through supplementation rather than diet alone) can lead to [kidney stones](https://www.everydayhealth.com/kidney-stones/guide/)among people who are prone to them. Too much vitamin C can also lead to stomach trouble, including diarrhea, nausea, and stomach cramps. Research and Statistics: How Many People Have Scurvy?
